Her younger son helps her with this business, since the older one works. But what she doesn’t like is to stay up late and not sleep well on the weekends. However, she knows that the economic earnings are very good, and that if she wants to move forward, she must make some sacrifices. She hopes that soon she will achieve her goals, including owning a shop.

This is her second loan with MFP, and what she likes about working in her communal bank is the responsibility of each member. With the money that she requests, she will buy her own cases for beer, since the ones that she has now are borrowed, and in this way she can make better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase merchandise

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
With a 1 hectare (2.5-acre) rice field, Roseline D. manages a rice farming business. She is 47 years old and lives in Norala, South Cotabato with her four children. Her eldest son is still 20 years old. The earnings from her farm helped a lot during the time when her son was applying for a job.

Since 1988, Roseline has been running this kind of business and, on May 2008, she joined Community Economic Ventures Inc. because it helps farmers in their locality by providing financial assistance with a low interest rate.

Today, Roseline is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 to continue with her farming business.

loans.use: To use for farm financing

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo is 57 years old and lives in the village of Parog-Parog, Solana, Cagayan, with his wife, Filomena. They are blessed with five children: Marierose, 25 years old, a college graduate presently working at Sowesfaco in their village; Emmanuel, 24 years old, a high school graduate; Dominador, 21 years old, a college student taking Information Technology; Julius, 18 years old, a college student taking an automotive course; C., 17 years old, also a college student taking Hotel Management.

Alfredo and Filomena are striving hard to earn income to satisfy their daily needs especially in providing for the education of their children. Alfredo works as a farmer and his crops are rice and vegetables, while his wife cooks different viands (tasty dishes) and snacks that she sells in their village.

Alfredo wants to borrow additional farming and vending capital of PHP 18,000 from Kiva lenders that he can use for the maintenance of their farming business. Their PHP 25,000 gross farming income every harvest season is not enough because of the high interest rate that traders put on their debts.

Alfredo is hoping that his loan request will be granted for it will not only assist his business but also the needs of his family. He is just hoping that, through wise farming management and patience, they will able to uplift their living conditions.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for his farming business

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia P., a 54-year-old farmer, strives to manage her rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. Her farm's income meets her family's basic needs and pays the tuition fees for her seven children.

In May 2008 Nelia joined Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) in the hope that her farm could be financed with low interest. She is now requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP. She will use it to buy farm inputs and make her business grow.

loans.use: To finance her farm, e.g. buy farm inputs

loans.name: Hugo

texts.es:
Hugo tiene 34 años, vive con su esposa (Gladis), de 32 años, y con sus 3 hijos: Víctor de 14, Steven de 7 y Jefri de 5 años de edad.
Desde hace 14 años él se dedica a brindar el servicio de transporte de pasajeros, su padre también se dedicaba a ello y él optó por seguirlo, ya que desde muy joven le gustaron los vehículos. Por ello, actualmente se siente contento de realizar su trabajo, saliendo desde muy temprano en las mañanas, pues cree que mientras más se esfuerce, logrará mejores ganancias. Este pensamiento le está arrojando buenos resultados, ya que los ingresos son favorables y puede brindarle una buena calidad de vida a su familia, quienes son el motivo de su esfuerzo.

En el futuro él quiere comprar un carro de segunda mano con el cual pueda trabajar de manera más independiente, ya que el auto que usa actualmente es alquilado y debe dar parte de las ganancias de su trabajo a la persona que le arrienda el vehiculo.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP y promete ser muy puntual en todos los pagos, ya que se considera un apersona muy responsable. Con el dinero que solicita dará la primera cuota para poder conseguir el auto propio que tanto desea. Además, también debe realizar algunas refacciones al carro que maneja actualmente.
texts.en:
Hugo is 34 years old. He lives with his wife, Gladis, 32 years old, and their three children: Victor, 14, Steven, 7, and Jefri, 5 years old.

For 14 years, he has offered transportation services to his passengers. His father also worked in this, and he chose to follow him. Hence, since a very young age, he has liked vehicles. Therefore, he is very content now to do his work, leaving very early in the mornings. He believes that the more one strives, the better his gains. This thought is giving him good results, as the earnings are favorable, and he can offer a good quality of life to his family, who are the motive for his efforts.

In the future, he wants to purchase a second-hand car so that he can work independently. The car he uses now is rented, and he must pay part of his work earnings to the person that rents him the vehicle.

This is his first loan with MFP, and he promises to be punctual with all the payments. Already, he is considered a responsible person. With the money that he requests, he will put a down payment on his own car that he wants so much. Also, he will do some work on the car that he drives now.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Refurbishment of his working automobile

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene I. is a farmer in Norala, South Cotabato. During harvest, he earns 30,000 to 50,000 PHP from his 3.4-hectare rice field. He obtains finance at a high interest rate from a rice trader. That is why he joined Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI), which only charges 2 per cent interest per month.

Rene is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to financially support his farm and buy the required necessities. Such a loan is very helpful for farmers like Rene, who only have limited business capital.

loans.use: To finance his farm

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en: Bernardo G. started his rice farming business in 1967. Now, at the age of 61, he manages a one-hectare rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. He is grateful for joining Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI), because his farm will be financed at a lower interest compared to finance from a rice trader, which is high. Bernardo is currently requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to continue to finance his farm business.

loans.use: To finance his farm

loans.name: Junet

texts.es:
Juneth tiene 28 años y vive en su apacible hogar con Willy, de 37 años, y con sus pequeños hijos; Edilma de 14 y Arnol de 5 años.
Ella se dedica al bordado de hermosas figuras en chompas de lana, desde hace 5 años, tiempo en el cual se animó a realizar esta actividad en la tranquilidad de su casa, lo cual que le proporciona creatividad para formar estas figuras que toman vida en cada chompa que termina.

Una amiga le enseñó este arte del bordado en chompas, y desde entonces, trabaja sin parar. A Juneth le hacen grandes cantidades de pedidos y tiene dos semanas para entregar las chompas bordadas, además considera este negocio rentable ya que sus principales herramientas son sus trabajadoras manos, agujas, lanas y toda su imaginación. También le ha enseñado el bordado a su hija Edilma, quien continuará con el legado artístico de su madre. Para el futuro piensa instalar una tienda de ropa o una surtida librería. 

Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y se compromete a ser puntual en sus pagos y trabajar con mucho esmero en su banco comunal. Además, para el futuro, piensa solicitar más créditos para lograr cumplir las metas que se ha trazado en la vida. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará materiales para seguir con sus bordados y otra parte lo invertirá en el negocio de su esposo, que vende ropa en las distintas provincias del Perú.
texts.en:
Juneth is 28 years old and lives in her cozy home with Willy, 37, and their young children: Edilma, 14 and Arnol, 5. For the past 5 years she has embroidered beautiful designs on wool sweaters, work which she is able to conduct in the peace and quiet of her own home, which provides her with an environment where she can be creative in producing these designs that seem to come to life on each sweater she completes. A friend taught her the art of emboidery and since then she has worked at it non-stop. Juneth receives a large number of orders and she must complete the items in two weeks. She considers this a profitable business since her main tools are her own hard-working hands, needles, wool, and all of her imagination. She has taught her daughter Edilma to embroider so she will continue with her mother's artistic legacy. For the future she would like to set up a clothing store or a well-stocked book store. This is her first loan with MFP and she pledges to be punctual with her rapayments and to work diligently with her communal bank. Also, for the future, she intends to request more loans in order to reach the goals she has set for herself. With the funds she is requesting on this occasion, she intends to purchase materials to continue her embroidery and part of it she will invest in her husband's business which is clothing sales in various provinces of Peru.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for her embroidery.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane G. is a 30-year-old rice farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She lives with her husband, Joey, and their six children. Their eldest child is 13 years old. Mary Jane manages a 1.5-hectare rice field, and the farm's income meets the family's basic needs.

Mary Jane now needs additional capital for her farming business. She has joined Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI), requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP. Provided with proper farm inputs, her farm would have a good and bigger harvest.

loans.use: To finance her farm, e.g. buy farm inputs

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda I. is 44 years old and lives in Norala, South Cotabato. She has three children, the eldest of whom is 15 years old. Rosalinda makes her living from rice farming and is able to send her children to school with the income she earns from her 1.5 hectare rice field.

Rosalinda would like to request a loan from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) for 15,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy supplies for her farm. It is very helpful for her to have additional capital for her business.

loans.use: To finance her farm, e.g. buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lisset

texts.es:
Lisset es una joven de 22 años, vive con sus padres y su hermano en su humilde casa ubicada en el populoso distrito de Ventanilla en Lima. Desde hace 5 años tiene una bodega en su vivienda, donde vende distintos productos comestibles. Al principio era el negocio de su madre, pero al no poder seguir con él, Lisset tomó la administración, ya que al ayudarla desde sus inicios le dieron la experiencia necesaria para sacarlo adelante. Algunas veces su joven hermano la ayuda en la atención, pues muchas veces ella debe salir a adquirir la mercadería para abastecerlo. 

Lisset es soltera, pero quiere trabajar desde su juventud para que en el futuro, cuando tenga familia, pueda brindarles lo mejor, gracias a sus esfuerzos. 
A ella le gusta su trabajo porque lo considera tranquilo y rentable, ya que no requiere tanto esfuerzo y las personas de su barrio compran seguido. 

En el futuro piensa ampliar su bodega con más productos comestibles para lograr obtener mejores ganancias. 

Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP y a pesar de su juventud, Lisset sabe que debe ser responsable, ya que los miembros de su banco comunal han depositado su confianza en ella. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mayor cantidad de productos para su tienda, además de cervezas, pues sabe que esta bebida le dará buenas ganancias.
texts.en:
Lisset is a youth of 22 years. She lives with her parents and brother in their humble home located in the populated district of Ventanilla in Lima. For 5 years, she has had a small shop in their home, where she sells different consumables. In the beginning, it was her mother’s business, but when she could not continue with it, Lisset took over running the store. She had been helping since its beginnings, which gave her the experience necessary to move ahead with it. Sometimes her younger brother helps her attend the store, because often she has to leave to get merchandise to stock it.

Lisset is single, but she has wanted to work since her youth because in the future, when she has a family, she wants to offer them the best, thanks to her efforts.

She likes working, because she thinks its relaxed and profitable. It doesn’t require too much work, and the people in the neighborhood go on purchasing.

In the future, she hopes to grow her shop with more consumable products to achieve better earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase merchandise

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina is 61 years old and married to Quirino, a farmer. They have eight children, five of whom are already married. They live happily with their grandchildren at San Pablo, Alicia, Isabela.

Felomina has managed a poultry business for almost nine years and her net monthly income is 3,000 PHP. She now wants to borrow 12,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to purchase some chickens and additional cages. She believes that "From hard work comes a bountiful gift".

loans.use: To purchase chickens and cages

loans.name: Mery

texts.es:
Mery tiene 44 años, vive con su esposo y sus 5  hijos; 2 mayores de edad, Angie de 23 y Grace de 20; y 3 menores, Mery de 11, Jhonny de 9 y Antuannete de 5 años. Todos viven en su casa propia que es de material noble y está ubicada en el populoso distrito de Ventanilla, en Lima.
Ella tiene una pequeña bodega en su casa y desde hace tres años la volvió a establecer, ya que durante un tiempo la dejó al olvido. La comodidad de este negocio en su hogar la animó a continuar con él, ya que le era muy  rentable para lograr sostener a su familia. Mery peude trabajar en la comodidad de su casa y a la vez atender a sus hijos menores y en estas labores la ayuda amablemente su esposo Oscar. 

El momento difícil y en el que según ella “corretea más”, es al mediodía, ya que atender a los clientes se le junta con la hora de almuerzo en la que debe atender a su familia también. Mery atiende en su bodega casi el día entero y los fines de semana el horario de atención puede llegar a extenderse hasta la medianoche.

Para el futuro piensa arreglar las instalaciones de su  negocio, abastecerlo con más mercadería y hasta llegar a vender comida afuera de su casa.

Ya ha tenido 4 créditos a través de MFP y le ha gustado siempre colaborar con su banco comunal, pero por cuestiones de tiempo esta vez pide un préstamo individual. La mitad del dinero que solicita lo destinará a comprar más mercadería, mientras la otra mitad será para arreglar su local, esto para darle una mejor presentación ante sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mery is 44 years old. She lives with her husband and their five children. Two are already grown, Angie, 23 years old, and Grace, 20. Three are younger: Mery, 11, Jhonny, 9, and Antuannete, 5 years old. They all live in her home made from simple materials and located in the popular Ventanilla district in Lima.

She has a small shop in her home and has returned to it after three years, during which time she had to leave it aside. The convenience of having this business in her own home inspired her to continue with it, since it has been very profitable and can sustain her family. Mery can work in the comfort of her home and, at the same time, care for her younger children. Her husband, Oscar, also cheerfully helps with the work.

The hardest time, according to her means “run around more,” is midday, since she has to attend to her customers on their lunch hour and also to her family. Mery attends the store almost the entire day and on weekends the hours can extend until midnight.

In the future, she thinks she will update the facilities in her business, stock it with more merchandise and eventually sell food from outside her home.

She has already had 4 loans with MFP, and she has always liked collaborating with her communal bank, but for matters of time, she is requesting an individual loan this time. Half of the money that she requests will be used to purchase more merchandise, while the other half will be used to update her shop in order to have a good appearance for her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase merchandise

loans.name: Venerada

texts.es:
Veneranda es una mujer luchadora, a sus 45 años siempre piensa proyectándose para un futuro mejor. Vive con su esposo (Edmundo), de 45 años, y sus hijos Emily de 21 y Eder de 20 años en su casa propia.

Ella se levanta desde muy temprano para atender a su familia y durante la tarde empieza la preparación de sus salchipapas (papas y salchichas fritas), para ofrecerlas a sus habituales comensales. Venerando vende este platillo en un carrito salchipapero que saca afuera de su casa y por la exquisitez de su comida es muy conocida en su vecindario, además a ella le gusta su negocio porque es rentable y las salchipapas son de fácil preparación. 

Para el futuro quiere tener un restaurante de comida en su casa, pues es bastante amplia y ya está pensando dónde podría ir ubicado todo. Esta emprendedora señora también tiene un negocio de venta de discos musicales y día a día se las ingenia para salir adelante 

Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y promete ser responsable, como siempre, con todos sus pagos; además está muy conforme con su trabajo en su banco comunal, pues todos se conocen y son puntuales.

Para hacer realidad su sueño del restaurante, Veneranda invertirá el dinero que solicita en implementar su casa y para eso empezará por el acabado del piso y la compra de algunos muebles para poner los CDs que vende.
texts.en:
Veneranda is a hard-working woman who, at 45 years of age, always is thinking of a better future. She lives in her own home with her husband , Edmundo, who is 45 years old, and their two children, Emily, 21, and Eder, 20. She starts her day very early in the morning seeing to her family and in the afternoon she prepares salchipapas (which is a dish made of potatoes and fried sausage) for her regular customers. Veneranda sells this dish from a vending cart which she puts outside her home and, thanks to the tastiness of her meals, she is very well-known in her neighborhood. Besides, she likes her work because she makes good profits and the dishes are easy to prepare. For the future, she would like to have a restaurant in her home since it is quite roomy and she is thinking that she could site the entire operation at home. This enterprising woman also sells records and daily looks for ways to get ahead. This is her third loan with MFP and she promises to be responsible, as usual, with all her repayments. Also, she is very happy with her work with the communal bank since all members know each other and are punctual. To make her restaurant dream come true, Veneranda will invest these funds in refitting her house beginning with new flooring and some new furniture to display the CDs she sells.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her future restaurant.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
Víctor es un joven de 25 años, cuya pasión es la música, el vive con su pareja, sus hermanas y sus sobrinos en una acogedora casa ubicada cerca a un balneario al norte de la ciudad de Lima.

Desde hace 7 años toca la guitarra en el grupo musical “Los imbatibles del escenario” y comparte este oficio musical con su hermana, quien es la vocalista de dicho grupo y casi siempre lo representa, ya que Victor está siempre ocupado por sus múltiples obligaciones, por ello es ella quien aparece en la foto.

A Víctor le agrada hacer música, sabe que le alegra la vida a las personas que la escuchan y asisten seguido a sus conciertos. Tocar música vernacular es rentable porque mueve masas y esto lo saben los integrantes de “Los Imbatibles del Escenario”, quienes se esfuerzan por llegar a ser un grupo reconocido en el Perú. 

Este joven guitarrista quiere modernizar los equipos electrónicos del grupo para lograr mayor aceptación y crecer musicalmente. 

Este es el segundo préstamo que él tiene con MFP y promete ser responsable y puntual, como en cada uno de sus conciertos. Le gusta conformar su banco comunal porque todos los integrantes son honestos. Con el dinero que solicita es para la compra de un equipo y parlantes nuevos para que el grupo vernacular siga produciendo música de calidad.
texts.en:
Victor is a 25-year-old young man whose passion is music. He lives with his partner, his sisters and his nieces and nephews in a cozy house near a beach resort north of Lima. For the past 7 years he has played the guitar in the musical group "Los Imbatibles del Escenario" (The Stage Unbeatables) and he shares this work with his sister who is the group's vocalist and agent and, because Victor is always busy with his many obligations, it is her image that appears in the photo. Victor loves to make music because he knows it makes people happy and they attend his performances often. To play popular music is good business because it moves the masses and the members of "Los Imbatibles del Escenario" know this and therefore wish to become a group reknown in all Peru. This young musician wants to modernize the group's electronic equipment to have a better public acceptance and to grow musically. This is the second loan with MFP and he promises to be responsible and punctual with his repayments as he is with every show. He enjoys being part of the communal bank because all the members are honest. With these funds he will purchase new sound equipment so that the popular group will continue to produce music of quality.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase speakers.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda tiene 27 años, vive en su casa propia con su hijo, Jefferson, de 6 años de edad. Ella es una mujer muy trabajadora que gracias a lo aprendido de niña, hoy en día puede solventar los gastos de su hogar. El tejido de chompas, guantes, chalinas, etc. es la actividad a la que se dedica y le gusta mucho, ya que deja volar su imaginación y en cada prenda que realiza pone gran dedicación y esfuerzo para logar el acabado ideal. Además, con este trabajo se siente muy independiente, lamentablemente debe realizarlo durante prácticamente todo el día, lo cual le resulta muy cansado, pero Yolanda con gran dedicación se esmera en realizarlo de la mejor manera. 

Ella quiere en un futuro incursionar en otro tipo de negocio y es por eso que ha estado pensando comprar ropa y calzado para vender en otras ciudades, pero para ello tendría que viajar muy frecuentemente.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Yolanda con MFP y siempre se ha caracterizado por ser muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará mayor cantidad de lana y material para sus tejidos y si fuera posible un maquina tejedora.
texts.en:
Yolanda is 27 years old and lives in her own home with her 6 year-old son, Jefferson. She is a hard-working mother who, thanks to what she learned as a young girl, is today able to take care of household expenses. She knits sweaters, mittens, shawls, etc., an activity which she enjoys very much and that lets her imagination take flight with each garment she produces. With each garment she pays attention to every detail to make sure it is finished in an ideal manner. Besides, this work allows her to be independent. However, she must work practically all day, which is very tiring but Yolanda is very dedicated and works hard to accomplish her tasks in the best manner possible. She wants in the future to become involved in a new kind of enterprise and is thinking of buying clothing and footwear to sell in other cities but this would require her to travel frequently. This is her second loan with MFP and she has always been characterized by being very punctual with her repayments. With these funds she intends to buy large quantities of wool and other materials needed for her knitting and, if possible, a knitting machine.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wool.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: He wants to enlarge his farm

loans.name: Jolita

texts.en: Jolita C. is from the village of Lugait, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Jolita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jolita owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Jolita is just starting this business. In 2009, Jolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jolita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jolita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Yedgor

texts.ru: Едгор Темуров проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Едгор более 2 лет занимается торговлей. Он имеет собственный магазин, в котором торгует продуктами питания. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота и увеличения ассортимента, т.к. в этом есть спрос.
texts.en:
Yedgor T. lives in the city of Kulyab. He is 40 years old, married and has five children. Yedgor has been engaged in trade for more than two years. He has his own store, in which he sells food products. He is requesting a loan to expand his inventory and diversify his assortment in order to meet demand.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand inventory

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.ru: Кукузова Гулсара проживает в Яванском районе. Возраст 37 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Муж находится на заработках в России. Гулсара более 5 лет занимается земледелием. Она в основном выращивает пшеницу и овощи, а потом продает их в магазине брата.  Кредит просит для закупа минеральных удобрений и семян, для нового посева урожая.
texts.en:
Gulsara K. lives in the Yavan region. She is married and has two children. Her husband is now working in Russia. Gulsara has been in agriculture for more than five years. She grows mainly wheat and vegetables and then sells it at her brother's store. She is asking for a loan to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds for sowing new harvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Pir

texts.ru: При Тошбоев проживает в Яванском районе. Возраст 47 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Жена у себя дома занимается пашивкой одежды. Сам же Пир более 6 лет занимается перевозками пассажиров, т.е. предоставлением услуги такси. До этого он более 15 лет работал "учителем", по специальности. Кредит просит для ремонта автомашины.
texts.en:
Pir T. lives in the Yavan region. He is 47 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife sews clothing at home. Pir himself has been transporting passengers as a taxi driver for more than six years. Before that he has worked as a teacher for more than fifteen years. He is asking for a loan to repair his auto.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair auto

loans.name: Maylinda

texts.en:
Maylinda M. is from the village of Poblacion, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old. Maylinda is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Maylinda owns & operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing & selling wood products to local businesses and community members. Maylinda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maylinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maylinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Maylinda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase machinery to expand the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maylinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase machinery to expand the business

loans.name: Jannette

texts.en:
Twenty-eight-year-old Jannette G. is the mother of a 1-year-old child. She is starting to save for her child's future education. She manages a one-hectare rice field and a sari-sari store. Farming is the main source of income for her family.

She has joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP. With low interest, she would be able to finance her farm and save more for her child's education.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna P. owns a one-hectare rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. Now, at the age of 47, she manages a rice farming business. It is the main source of income for her family. She has 5 children; the eldest is 20 years old. She provides for the education of her children through farming.

It's a big help for her to join Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because she will be helped in financing her farm business with a low interest of 2 percent per month only. She's requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to sustain her business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Rice farming and duck raising are the source of income of Helen B.. She started her business in 2001. Now she has a 2-hectare rice field and 497 heads of duck. Now, at 45 years old, she has 5 children. She was able to sustain her family through this kind of business.

She would like to request a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in order for her to have additional capital to buy ducks and farm supplies.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a 46-year-old widow with five children aged between 15 and 23 years, all of whom go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house in the outskirts of Kampala where she lives with six people. She also takes care of additional family members.

Agnes owns a stall at her home where she sells charcoal. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for three years and is servicing her sixth loan. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises because she works from her home.

Agnes sells to all categories of people both in retail and wholesale. She buys sacks of charcoal from Kyankwanzi in Mubende district and so she incurs transport costs to and from villages. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season.

Agnes wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow stronger and to begin selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Felecita

texts.en: Felecita C. is from the village of Matco. She is 58 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Felecita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2002, Felecita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Felecita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 13th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema is a 35 years old widow with two children aged 15 and 17 years.  All of her children go to school. She resides and rents a two roomed house where she is staying with four people. Besides her children, Rehema does not take care of additional family members. She is a tailor in Mengo, sewing dresses and school uniforms.  She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for three years, servicing her sixth loan.  She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises because she works from her home. Rehema sells to all categories of people in both retail and whole sale volumes. She buys her supplies of clothing material from the Kampala city shops and most pay transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season, as she works from an open place. Rehema wants to use this loan to buy more clothing material.She aspires to see her business grow stronger and of owning a fashion and designing shop.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of clothing materials

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna, 46 years old, is married to Cornelio B., and they are blessed with four children: Marvin - 21 years old, fourth year college student at Isabela State University; Maybel - 16 years of age, a high school graduate; Morena - 15 years of age, in fourth year high school at Villa Concepcion National High School, and Mark Carlo - 7 years old, a grade one pupil. Their house is located near the Barangay hall and elementary school.

Myrna has managed a typical village store for almost a year now, earning a daily net income PHP 500.00. Her husband, who works as an electrician, a farmer, and a private driver, earns PHP 1,000.00 for each trip. Myrna is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000.00 from KIVA lenders for the additional requirements of her business. She is hopeful that the loan will result in increased income from her store.

loans.use: Additional capital in her retail store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Solmira

texts.en:
Solmira, 36 years old, has managed a livestock business for almost five years, raising both hogs and ducks. She has also been engaged in vegetable vending for eight months. In order to make her business more productive, Solmira is requesting a loan of PHP8,000 from KIVA lenders to purchase feed for her hogs and ducks. She hopes that the lenders will help her to earn more income and attain her business goals.

Solmira is married to Apolinario and blessed with five children: James - 27 years of old, a tricycle driver; Emerson - 26 years old, a farmer; Tayrene - 24 years old, a full-time housewife; Arnold - 22 years old, a college student, and Jonard - 16 years old, a fourth year high school student.

loans.use: Additional capital for her livestock business

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma C., from the village of Lugait, Misamis Oriental, is a 44-year-old married mother of seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns and operates a business whose main source of income comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Wilma is just starting this business.

In 2009, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma is requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en: Sonia P. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old and is married. Sonia owns and operates a specialized "sari-sari" (variety) retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Sonia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores C. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old, is married, and has four adult children.

Dolores owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. Dolores is just starting this business.

In 2009, Dolores joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca, who is 54 years old, manages a fish pond business within her village. She is widowed and has been blessed with four children but all of them are already married.

Francisca would like to develop her fish pond so that she is able to earn a bigger profit for her family needs. In this regard, she is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. She will be glad if this loan amount is granted.

loans.use: To develop her fish pond

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 42 years old and is married with four children aged 6 to 20 years, all of whom go to school. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house where she lives with eight people. She also takes care of additional family members.

Christine is a retailer, selling secondhand shoes and ladies’ bags. She works in Mengo in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for three years and with MCDT for three years and is servicing her sixth loan. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises because she works from her home. Besides this business, she also sells herbal medicine.

Christine sells to all categories of people, both in retail and wholesale. She buys ladies secondhand bags and shoes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season as she works in an open place.

Christine wants to use this loan to buy more secondhand bags and shoes. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow stronger and owning a whole shop of secondhand bags and shoes.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand shoes and bags

loans.name: Leonor

texts.en:
Leonor manages her little variety store located just in front of her house. As much as possible, she would like to maintain her business by having sufficient revolving capital. She hopes that lenders will again help her business by providing her with another loan of PHP 5,000. This amount will be used to purchase more commodities for her store.

Most of the time, her products are being taken out on credit. Through the loan she is trying to obtain, she knows that her business could make an instant recovery. She hopes that, as a previous client, the trust of lenders in her will again be provided.

Leonor is 23 years old and she is married to Allan who works on their own farm located in their village. The couple is blessed with one daughter who serves as their inspiration. Their family is residing peacefully in the village of Cabaruan, Naguillan, Isabela.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Direct selling is the business of Laila D. S.. She is married to Jonie D. S. who is engaged in their rice fields. They don’t have any children yet.

Laila sells MSE, Natasha and Sundance cosmetics products. She has been selling cosmetics and apparel for almost two years and has noticed that this kind of business really helps in improving their way of living. She is able to generate PHP 3,000 weekly from her business but she still needs to continue improving her business by buying more products because she has so many orders. 

Laila would like to borrow additional capital of PHP 5,000 which will allow her to purchase inventory for all the orders she has. She hopes that her loan request will be approved; it would serve as a big help in improving their way of living. Laila is looking forward to the betterment of their living standard.

loans.use: To buy more products to fill her orders

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver is 60 years old and is married with seven children aged 28 to 40 years. None of her children goes to school; it’s only the grand children who are schooling. Oliver resides in and owns a seven-roomed house where she lives with six people. She also takes care of additional family members.

Oliver is a food vendor, selling all types of foodstuffs at her home in Mengo Kaswa Zone in the outskirts of Kampala. On average she receives twenty customers a day. She has been in this business for one year and with MCDT for three years and is servicing her sixth loan. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises because she works from her home.

Oliver sells to all categories of people, both in retail and wholesale. She buys her foodstuffs from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season as she works in an open space.

Oliver wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sweet potatoes, cassava and bunches of bananas. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow stronger and to start buying directly from farmers.

loans.use: To buy sacks of sweet potatoes, cassava and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en: Leonisa D. is from the town of Malibangcao, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Leonisa owns and operates a "carinderia" (an eatery), preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Leonisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leonisa is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Luzonia

texts.en:
Luzonia resides in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela and has already been widowed for six years. At the age of 47, she is still sending two of her children to elementary school. She has seven children and most of them are already married.

Luzonia is involved in retailing cosmetics and apparel from DXN Company, making a net profit which is already sufficient for her needs. She hopes to obtain a loan of PHP 3,000 to have additional revolving capital to further improve her business. She wants to have additional items to sell to her customers.

Luzonia still dreams of managing a general store someday. She couldn’t start her dream business so far due to insufficient capital. She hopes that someday, when she is capable of obtaining a larger loan, she will put her dreams into reality.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is 30 years old and is the single mother of four children aged 3 to 14 years, all of whom go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with four people. She also takes care of additional family members.

Jalia sells secondhand clothes in the Natete markets in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for two years and is servicing her fourth loan. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises but pays daily market dues and pays for a trading license. Jalia sells to all categories of people both in retail and wholesale and, on average, she receives twenty customers a day.

Jalia buys her clothing from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season as she works in an open place.

Jalia wants to use this loan to buy more secondhand clothes. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow stronger and to going directly to importers.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo is 42 years old and he is married to Marilyn T., who is a teacher. They are blessed with two lovely children, Reymalyn, 23 years of age and a college graduate, and Mary Grace, 18 years of age and a 2nd-year college student. Their house is located in Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, a rural area that is 25 kilometers away from the city proper of Cauayan. 

Reynaldo's business is in front of their house, which is near a school. He has operated a junk shop business for almost three years. His weekly net income is PHP 1,000.00, and he helps his wife to earn more money for the education of their daughter. 

He plans to borrow PHP 5,000.000 to use as additional capital for his business so he can earn more income. He hopes that KIVA lenders will grant his loan as soon as possible so he can attain his goal of a better future of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital in his junk shop

loans.name: Olivia Nakintu 's Group

texts.en:
Olivia is a 33-year-old married woman with four children, ages 3 to 15 years old. All of her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she lives with six people. Olivia takes care of family members in addition to her children. The family has access to electricity, but no piped water. 

Olivia works in semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a stall where she sells second-hand clothes. She uses public transportation to travel to and from her shop. Olivia doesn’t pay rent for her stall, but she pays monthly dues and operating license fees. She is challenged by increasing clothing prices and buyers who borrow from her and then default. 

Olivia sells to all kinds of people and receives about 20 customers a day. Olivia works seven days a week. Her monthly expenses include medication and food for her family. She has been in the clothing business for ten years and she has been a member of MCDT for eight years. She is now servicing her sixteenth loan, working with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more used clothing.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes, such as skirts, shirts, and blouses

loans.name: Wassiatou

texts.fr: A. Wassiatou est née en 1974 à Ifangni dans le Département du Plateau. Wassiatou est mariée à ABOUDOU Raoufou, un peintre auto. Wassiatou et Raoufou ont deux enfants tous scolarisés et encore à leur charge. La famille vit à Agbodjèdo, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Wassiatou vend des divers (biscuits, bonbons, détergents, farine de manioc, etc. ) du maïs et la pâte de maïs. Wassiatou vend ses produits à domicile et de façon ambulante. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Wassiatou participe aux charges de la famille. Wassiatou a eu déjà de ALIDé deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Pour mieux développer son activité, Wassiatou sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Wassiatou was born in 1974 in Ifangni in Plateau County. She is married to ABOUDOU Raoufou, an automobile painter. Wassiatou and Raoufou have two children who are both in school and still in their care. The family lives in Agbodjèdo, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Wassiatou sells various goods (cookies, candy, detergents, cassava flour, etc.), corn, and cornmeal mash. She sells her merchandise out of her house and door-to-door. Thanks to the revenues from her business, she helps to cover family expenses. She has had two ALIDé loans that she has repaid. To develop her business further, she’s requesting a third ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cookies, candy, corn, and cassava flour

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is 29 years old and married with two children. She sells groceries. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Mrs. Emma O. is a 35-year-old married woman who is blessed with 2 children. She farms corn and she just harvested her corn crop. Her income from the harvested crop is only enough for her family’s needs. Emma needs additional capital to be able to buy corn seed. She has requested a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures. This loan will help Emma to start planting corn on her farm again.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: K. Martine

texts.fr: T. K. Martine est née en 1949 à Dassa dans le Département des Collines. Martine est mariée à TOSSA Bernadin. Martine et Bernadin ont cinq enfants tous majeurs et indépendants. La famille vit à Agbodjèdo, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Martine vend des divers (produits contre les moustiques, éponges en fer, savons, allumettes, piles pour les lampes torches, etc.) ainsi que le charbon de bois. Martine vend ses produits à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. Martine a déjà eu trois crédits de ALIDé qu'elle a bien remboursés et lesquels elle a élevé le niveau de son activité. Aujourd'hui, Martine sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé pour pouvoir continuer de développer son activité.
texts.en:
T. K. Martine was born in 1949 in Dassa in Collines County. She is married to TOSSA Bernadin. Martine and Bernadin have five children who are legal adults and independent. The family lives in Agbodjèdo, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Martine sells various goods (anti-mosquito products, steel sponges, soaps, matches, flashlight batteries, etc.), as well as charcoal. She sells her merchandise out of her home and also door-to-door. She has already had three ALIDé loans that she has repaid. She used them to raise her business level. Today, she’s requesting a fourth ALIDé loan to be able to continue developing her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal, detergents, insecticide, batteries, etc.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina C. is from the village of Brgy. Santiago in Iligan City. She is 38 years old. Rosalina is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalina sells scrap metal and other used products in the local community. Rosalina is just starting this business.

In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP that she will use to expand her business. This will be Rosalina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en: Rice and corn are the major agricultural crops in Agusan Del Sur. Adelfa, a 27-year-old married woman, is one of those who tills their farm for corn. She experienced failure in farming, but is also thankful for the income that she’s able to generate from her farm because it is a big help to her family. A member of CEV for 2 years, she is now requesting a loan of Php 8,000. She will use this loan for farm supplies, like fertilizers, to ensure that her crops are healthy.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en: Having gone through failure, Rosario does not allow herself to dwell on the past; instead, she goes on with her life. At 38, she is married and has 5 children to love and care for. She carefully tends her corn farm to achieve a good harvest. Rosario’s family depends on the income from her farm for their daily needs. A member of CEV, she requested for a loan of Php 12,000. She will use this loan to acquire the supplies that she needs for her farm.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda, age 58, is a corn farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has 7 children. Before joining CEV, she did not have enough money to buy farm supplies. High interest rates made borrowing difficult. Now, Florenda is thankful that she joined CEV. She can now purchase farm supplies with cash and repay a loan with low interest rates. 

She has requested a loan of Php 12,000 from CEV. Florenda will user her loan to buy the supplies that she needs to produce a healthy crop and a good harvest

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Mayjie

texts.en:
Mayjie is 36 years old and he drives a van. He would like to borrow PHP 5,000 to maintain his passenger van so that he can avoid accidents during his travels. Mayjie is hoping that he can borrow funds to repair his van. This will make his driving comfortable and satisfy his passengers.

Mayjie is separated, but still wants to earn more income for his new family. He hopes that he can overcome his trials in life. His dream is to achieve his goals and succeed in life.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of his van

loans.name: Nicasio

texts.en: Like other farmers, Nicasio has experienced failure, but this doesn’t stop him from farming. He plants corn on his farm. Nicasio is a member of CEV and is now requesting his fourth loan. He wants to borrow Php 10,000 to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies that he needs. Hopefully, with this financing, Nicasio's farm will not fail.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Sweetie Pie

texts.en:
Sweetie Pie sells many commodities in her little variety store, which is located in her village. She also sells frozen foods. She makes an income that is sufficient for her children’s daily allowances. She hopes to pursue her store to provide more for her family. 

Sweetie Pie would a loan of PHP 11,000 to continue to develop her store. She plans to use the loan to buy more items to sell. She hopes that, with her loan, she can expand her business further.

Sweetie Pie is 42 years old. She lives with her husband who is a tricycle operator in their village. The couple has three children who are currently in school. The family lives in the village of Magsaysay in Naguilian, Isabela.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Ma. Antoniette

texts.en:
Ma. Antoniette C. is from the village of Barangay Santiago in Iligan City. She is 28 years old. Ma. Antoniette is separated from spouse and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Ma. Antoniette owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Ma. Antoniette has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ma. Antoniette joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Antoniette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. She used her previous loan to buy new items to expand her product offering. Ma. Antoniette is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP that she will use to buy additional products to sell. This will be Ma. Antoniette's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Thèrèse

texts.fr: S. Thèrèse est née en 1962 à Adja dans le Département du Mono. Thèrèse est mariée à AKOHOUE François. Thèrèse et François ont quatre enfants tous majeurs et indépendants. La famille vit à Agbodjèdo, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Thèrèse vend des beignets de haricot et de l'igname frit pour le diner devant son domicile. Les tubercules d'igname et le haricot que Thèrèse utilise pour ses repas sont achetés à Kokoro, une localité du Centre Bénin où les produits vivriers sont moins chers. Thèrèse est une ancienne bénéficiaire de ALIDé qui est à sixième crédit avec ALIDé. Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle en perpétuelle croissance, Thèrèse sollicite de nouveau un crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Thèrèse was born in 1962 in Adja in Mono County. She is married to AKOHOUE François. Thèrèse and François have four children who are all legal adults and independent. The family lives in Agbodjèdo, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Thèrèse sells bean fritters and fried yams for dinner in front of her home. The yam tubers and the beans that she uses for her meals are purchased in Kokoro, a town in central Benin where staple foods are less expensive. Thèrèse is a former ALIDé recipient and is on her sixth loan with ALIDé. To satisfy further her ever-growing number of customers, she’s requesting a new ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of beans, yam tubers, and containers of vegetable oil

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena C. is from the village of Santiago in Iligan City. She is 30 years old. Nena is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Nena sells seafood, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Nena is just starting this business.

In 2009, Nena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP that she will use to buy items to sell. This will be Nena's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more seafood to sell

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo D. C. is 53 years old and his wife, Julieta, is only 31 years old. Although there is a big difference in their ages, they truly love each other. Their house is located along the national highway. Most roads in their village are not fully developed because their area is rural. 

They are blessed with three children. Marites, age 22, is a farmer; Erimalen, age 20, owns a retail store in their village; and their youngest child, Roderick, age 18, is a farmer. All of the children are married.

Rodolfo and his wife sell gas engines. His daily net income is PHP 100.00. In addition, they buy and sell carabao (water buffalo) that cost PHP 15,000.00, and they have a three-hectare (7.5-acre) corn farm. During every crop season, their net income is PHP 20,000.00. 

To get additional capital, he has decided to apply his first loan of PHP 6,000.00 from Kiva lenders. He wants to buy gasoline to sell so he can increase his income. He hopes that Kiva will grant his loan as soon as possible.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy gasoline to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Atuk

texts.en:
Atuk R. sells beer at a bar. She is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Atuk is 30 years old. Her husband is a peasant. She has 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a lorry to carry crates of beer from the White Bull breweries to her bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma E. sells fruits, such as mangoes, guava, and tomatoes. She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell. Wilma is 30 years old. Her husband is a peasant. She has 2 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married and has one child. She sells women's clothing at the central market in Kherson. She has been in this business for 3 years. During this time, she has learned that there is a large and constant demand for the items she sells. She also learned that, to be successful in sales, one needs to have large variety and good client service. She feels this is something she can do well. 

Natalya, her husband Andrei, and their 11 year old son, Daniel, live in a small apartment. Both son and husband support Natalya in her business. Natalya would like to borrow 8,780 UAH to increase the assortment of goods that she sells. She hopes to make additional profit and spend it on current family needs.

loans.use: To buy more and different goods to sell

loans.name: Isikulu

texts.en:
E. is 44 years old and married with six children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria.

E. sells fufu in retail to her customers. Fufu is prepared from fermented cassava. E. hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more cassava to cook more fufu to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more cassava to make more fufu

loans.name: Rekele

texts.en:
Rekele C. sells fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil to sell. Rekele is 29 years old and is widowed. She has 4 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca sells groceries and foodstuffs within her community in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She is 65 years old and married with seven children. She has been in this business for four years.

Rebecca hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and groceries to sell

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion S. lives in the village of Sto. Pamandayan, Brgy. Buenavista, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She is 48 years old and is married to Simplicio S., who works as a laborer on one of the haciendas (sugar plantations) in their locality. To earn additional income for the family, he also plants sugar cane on a small parcel of land that the couple owns. The couple has 6 children between the ages of 13 and 28 years old. Consolacion hopes to provide her children with good education so that they can have great jobs in the future.

Since she takes care of the family's finances, Consolacion knew for a fact that even if her husband worked twice as hard, his income would still not be enough to support their family, much less provide their children the future to which they aspired. To address this dilemma, Consolacion joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in January 1996 and used her loan of PHP 2,000 to start a retail business selling bananas. She reinvested  the income to buy more bananas to sell. As time went on, and her income improved and she was also able to borrow larger amounts.

Later, Consolacion started a business selling bingka (coconut and rice cakes) in their community. Then she diversified into charcoal sales, increasing her income potential even further. She also used the income to continue expanding her businesses and cultivating the family's sugar cane farm. All of these activities earn her a cumulative monthly income of PHP 10,000, which they use for their children's education and to support their businesses.

Because Consolacion has been a member with a good credit track record, she was able to borrow PHP 16,000 for her previous loan, which she used to add to her working capital her businesses and their sugarcane farm. Now that she has repaid the loan, she is again borrowing PHP 16,000. She plans to use the loan funds as additional capital for her business, to buy fertilizer, and to cultivate their sugar cane farm.

In the photo, Consolacion is shown in her sugar cane farm when the fields have recently been harvested and must be readied for planting.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sugar cane farm and her businesses

loans.name: Lalam

texts.en:
Lalam E. sells charcoal at home. She is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell. Lalam is 27 years old. Her husband is a security guard. She has 3 children who children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy charcoal to sell

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian C.’s hands are always full attending to her array of businesses. She is 45 years old and lives along Leveriza Street in Pasay City with her husband Edwin, aage 40, and their nine children.

Vivian's general store is her largest source of income. She also rents an extension of their house to student boarders and transients, she sells cosmetics and apparel, and she sells electronic load credits for mobile phones. She juggles all these business activities. Her combined monthly income reaches P 68,000.00 per month. She budgets her profit for her family’s daily basic needs, especially the education of her children.

Vivian is now on her 6th loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She is applying for a new loan of P 25,000.00 to use as additional capital for her businesses. She will use part of the loan proceeds to purchase grocery items for her general store. Some will be used for her mobile phone electronic load credits.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

Joy is requesting the loan of N70,000 to purchase more groceries and plastics to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Anzhella

texts.en:
Anzhella is divorced and has one child. She sells women's shoes at Mukachevo open market. Her income is about 3,000 UAH per month.

Anzhella has been in this business for 4 years. High demand provides her with many clients. Anzhella has a good pricing and a discount policy that helps her to retain old clients and to attract new ones. This business is the only source of income for Anzhella and her son. She really wants to develop it even further.

Anzhella would like to borrow 7,500 UAH to purchase more seasonal inventory. She will use additional income to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventory.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen sells medicines and cosmetics to earn a living to meet the needs of her family. She is 51 years old and married with three children. She lives in Edo State, Nigeria.

Helen is requesting the loan of N70,000 to purchase more cosmetics and medicines to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more medicines and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Reth's Group

Khim, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he uses a motorbike with cart to transport passengers. This couple has five children. One of them is employed in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, one is a seller and the others attend the local school. Now Mrs. Reth H. needs some money to buy more drinks, glasses and vegetables to resell. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family living with this loan.

loans.use: To buy drinks, glasses and vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca S. is from the village of Colonia, Valencia City. She is 53 years old. Rebecca is married and has 7 adult children. Rebecca owns & operates a business making & selling food products in the local community. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rebecca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Rebecca is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products that she sells. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rebecca from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Rosejean

texts.en:
Rosejean B. is a 33-year-old transport service operator living in a populous village in Dasmarinas, Cavite. Her husband, Zacarias, 32, is a tricycle driver. Their only child is now in high school.

Rosejean has been managing a transport fleet for six years now.  She owns a passenger jeepney and two units of motorized tricycles plying varied routes around town. She employs a neighbor as a driver along with her husband.

She has just finished paying off her latest loan from CCT. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of P10,000.00 to have enough funds for the mechanical maintenance of her fleet.
