In 2009, Elisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Jonna May

texts.en:
Jonna May dreams of succeeding in life and wants to build a happy home with her husband and their one child.

Jonna May invested in rice farming and now owns 1.75 hectares (approx. 4.5 acres) of rice field. Her crops still need farm inputs so she has applied for a loan of PHP 7,000 from CEVI. This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and other inputs she needs for her farm.

loans.name: Jocyline

texts.en: Jocyline M., 46 years old, lives in Dasmarinas, Cavite, with her five children, two of whom are in college and high school respectively. For the last five years, Jocyline has been managing her general store located at her house. She has also been working hard on her piggery business. Along with her general store, she raises pigs to earn income to support her and her children’s education. She also sells fresh pork meat, taking her pigs to the butcher when they are ready for slaughtering. She earns P18,000 from these business activities. Jocyline became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative just last year. She has now applied for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of P11,000 to have funds available for the expansion of her general store. She will use a portion of the loan for the renovation of her house. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store and to renovate her house

loans.name: Mr. Churn Doeur Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fifteen people and they all live in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. Mr. Churn D. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field has infertile soil. Thus, he decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to support the field to make more crops. His wife, Mrs. T. Kim, is a pig breeder. Mr. Churn D. is 42 years old and the father of six children. One of them is a farmer, three are enrolled in the local school and the others are too young to work or study. Mrs. Pot Y., Mrs. Srea S., Mrs. Yom Y, and Mrs. Heu K. did not come to take loans but their husband did, so there are five men who are presented in the picture.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:

The main source of income in this business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, to the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

Gemma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the range of products offered. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gemma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Rukiri 2 Group

texts.en: B. Lucas is the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. He is a determined and hardworking man who owns a retail shop and an alcohol store in Nyarukika trading centre. He has done this for 15 years. He is 42 years old and married with 6 children, most of whom are in secondary school; he takes care of 2 dependants. Due to Lucas’ good service, he is able to make a sizable profit, which he uses to take care of his family and to acquire other family properties. Lucas would like to continue with his business; indeed, he wants to expand by offering more products and thus increasing income. He is seeking a loan to help restock his business with more products such as beer and wine, in order to make more of a profit. He is really grateful for his loans.

loans.use: restocking his retail shop and buying beer and wine

Mrs. Sarim P. is 40 years old and a widow with two children. One of them is a motorbike taxi driver and the other attends the local school.

Patricia is 40 years old and married with four children. She sells foodstuffs in retail to her customers within her community in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time.

Patricia hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

Mrs. Phorn L. is 47 years old and the mother of seven children. loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 27 year old mother of one child. She runs a boutique in pipeline area of Nairobi, a business she has been operating for the last one and a half years. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to her stock of clothes and cosmetics. She hopes to expand her business and open multiple outlets in Nairobi. She describes herself as hardworking and determined.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing them with financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company; this will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: purchasing more clothes and cosmetics

loans.name: Loryn

texts.en:
Loryn B., 26 years old, is one of the youngest CCT entrepreneurs in Dasmarinas, Cavite. She lives with her 25 year old husband Marvin, a factory worker, and their lone child, who is now in grade school.

Loryn sells electronic load credits for mobile phones. She employs two neighbors as store assistants. Loryn now earns P 13,600.00 a month. She sets aside large sums of her profits for her family's future. From her earnings, for instance, she was already able to purchase a motorized tricycle.  

She has just finished paying off her latest loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, of which she became a member only last year. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of P 10,000.00 so that she can have enough funds to restock on grocery items she also sells at her store.

Loryn wishes to have other store outlets in other parts of the town.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is a Christian organization dedicated to fighting poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves both urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: restocking grocery items to sell at her store

In the future, John Bosco would want to sell wholesale so that he could sell more and consequently have a happy and united family. texts.en:
Rose M. is 43 years old. She is a widow and takes care of six children aged 10 through 20. She lives in Nyarugenge district, in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Rose has owned a small shop selling clothing and sewing items since 2006. She works alone in the store during the hours it is open: from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. each day.

Rose is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing additional materials and clothes for sale and, hopefully, to make a greater monthly profit.

loans.use: To buy additional materials and clothes

loans.name: Gerevasio's Group

texts.en:
O. Gerevasio is the leader of his group in Ibanda. He is 34 years old and married with five children. He also takes care of two other dependents.

Gerevasio has a retail shop in Nyarukika Trading Centre that he has been running for ten years and from which he makes 100,000/= in weekly profits. He is successful because of his good customer-care skills and his spirit. In the future, he wants to turn his shop into a wholesale operation at which time he will have to shift to new premises in the main town.

Gerevasio needs a loan to help restock his shop by buying more goods in order to avoid shortages. He is such a hardworking and friendly man.

loans.use: To buy more goods for his store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Mabel is 36 years old and married with three children. She lives in Edo State, Nigeria.

Mabel has a store where she sells groceries. She hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

Mabel hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: This is Michael C., a successful 28-year-old fruit dealer from Silang, Cavite. He is married to Flordeliza, 27, an office worker. Their only child is now attending grade school. Michael has been a dealer of different varieties of bananas for six years. His place of business is in the nearby province of Laguna where he has regular customers for his bananas. To help him attend to his business, he has hired the services of three assistants. He makes a net income of P12,400 a month. Michael became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only last year but has been very impressed with the many social benefits for its community members. He is now on his 5th loan with the cooperative. He is in need of a new loan in the amount of P11,000 to use as additional capital. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for his business

loans.name: Hak

texts.en: Mrs. Hak P. lives in Tralanh village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Since her breeding pigs business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing five more piglets and pig food for breeding. Additionally, she wants to use the rest of money to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family living with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Sae Vorn, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Hak P. is 57 years old and the mother of four children. One of them is employed in a garment factory, one is a construction worker and the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To purchase five piglets, pig food, and a cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 27 years old and married with three children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria.

Patricia sells fish and foodstuffs to make a living. She hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more fish and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Leatitia

texts.en:
Leatitia K. is a 30-year-old widow with two children aged 10 and 12 years old. She lives in Kicukiro district in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Leatitia owns a restaurant serving the local community and has owned this successful establishment since 2004. The business employs seven persons from her community. The profits from her business allow her to pay school fees for her two children. As she owns a restaurant, providing food is not too difficult!

Leatitia is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to increase her profit through purchasing more equipment such as a larger fridge, a new blender and other equipment.

loans.use: To buy more equipment for her restaurant

loans.name: Jolven

texts.en:
Jolven A. is a successful 26-year old fruits dealer from Silang, Cavite.  Jolven has been selling different varieties of bananas for five years now.  He is happy that he is able to send money to his family in the Visayas, but he laments that income is low due to frequent heavy rain.

He is requesting a loan of $200 as additional capital for his banana dealership.  Jolven dreams of being able to work abroad and of starting his own family.
 
About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for fruits dealership

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Mrs. Chum N. is 48 years old and she lives in Kdei Tnaot village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. On this plantation, she faces a problem because her soil is infertile. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. She will use the rest of money to build piggery. Her husband, Mr. Some Uy, is a palm juice collector. This couple has two children who are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to build piggery.

loans.name: Brigite

texts.en:
Brigite N. is 29 years old and married with one child who is two years old. She lives in Nyarugenge district.

Brigite owns her small general store, which sells everything from clothes and towels to cups and plates. She has owned this shop for just two years and employs one other person. Their working hours are from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. each day.

With this loan, Brigite will have capital to expand her offerings and attract new customers and hopefully earn a greater profit to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Mr. Bunthoeun Touch Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eight people who all live in Chroung Sdau village in Takeo province make up the village bank loan. Mr. Bunthoeun T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. They all will use the loan for different purposes. He is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field of land to cultivate rice. On this plantation, he has a problem because his field is infertile. In order to solve this problem, Mr. Bunthoeun T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make the crops more productive. His wife, Mrs. Kim Sros, is a tailor. Mr. Bunthoeun T. is 33 years old and the father of three children who are enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Srey Loeng K. did not come to take a loan but her husband did, so he is presented in the picture instead.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 60 years old and is a widow with four children. She sells sarongs, foodstuffs and provisions to earn a living.

Victoria hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more sarongs and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Katlyn

texts.en:
Katlyn R. is a 26-year old single mother, and her child is now in pre-school.  They live in Munting Ilog, Silang, Cavite.  

Katlyn owns a general store.  She went into business in 2005.  Through the years, her general store grew steadily.  She uses her profits to support her child's education and their daily needs.   

She is now on her 3rd loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative which she joined last year.  She is requesting a loan of $200 which she will use the fund to purchase more items to sell in her general store.  Katlyn dreams of evolving her general store into a big grocery and that she and her child will have their own home someday.


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To increase stock for general store

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 30 years old and married without a child. She owns a bakery along with her husband and has been in the business since eight years.

Patricia is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more bags of flour and an oven for baking. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase an oven and bags of flour for baking

loans.name: Tomas Facitela

texts.pt:
Tomas Facitela M. nasceu em Inhambane tem 35 anos de idade, vive maritalmente é pai de três filhos com idades compreendidas entre os 1 aos 7 anos, o mais velho é que vai a escola. Para além não responsabiliza se por ninguém e consegue poupar 1.500.00MT ao mês, conta com ajuda do de um empregado dando lhe um valor de 1.000.00MT mensalmente.


Tomas sai Inhambane quando tinha 10 anos com seu tio para Suazilândia onde estudou ate a 8ª classe teve que interromper os estudos após a morte do seu tio. Sendo assim ele arranja um emprego nas Minas da África do Sul onde trabalhou num contrato de 5 anos, findo o contracto é indemnizado um valor de 80.000.00MT consecutivamente regressa a Moçambique e instala a sua residência em Namaacha na Fronteira de Suazilândia, e adquire uma carrinha que lhe facilita nos seus trabalhos diários. Hoje é vendedor ambulante (vende no carro) a mais de cinco anos tem vendido no mercado informal duas vazes por semana (quarta e sábado) das 7h às 17h tendo como melhor produto (farinha de milho, fruit, Omo e óleo vegetal) adquirido na vizinha Suazilândia comprando uma mercadoria de 20.000.00MT por viagem e tendo de lucro 5.500.00MT por mês. Aproxima se a hluvuku solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00MT para aumentar o volume dos seus produtos para satisfazer a necessidade dos clientes.


Este é o primeiro empréstimo de Tomas na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 15.000.00MT serão usados para aumentar o volume dos seus produtos, esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para construção do seu próprio estabelecimento e deixar de ser ambulante.
texts.en:
Tomas Facitela M. was born in Inhambane. He is 35 years old, married, and the father of 3 children with ages between 1 and 7 years old. The oldest is in school. Besides them he is not responsible for anyone else and is able to save 1,500MT each month. He counts on the help of an employee and pays him 1,000MT monthly. Tomas left Inhambane when he was 10 years old with his uncle to Swaziland where he went to school through the 8th grade. He had to interrupt his schooling after the death of his uncle. As such he was able to arrange a job in the mines of South Africa where he worked on a contract for 5 years. At the end of the contract he was compensated 80,000MT and consecutively he returned to Mozambique to set up his residence in Namaacha on the border of Swaziland. He acquired a wagon to help him with his daily work. Today he is a traveling vendor (sells from his car). For more than 5 years he has sold at the informal market two times week (Wednesday and Saturday) from 7:00am until 5:00pm. His best products are (corn flour, fruit, Omo, and vegetable oil) which he acquires in neighboring Swaziland. He purchases his goods for 20,000MT per visit, and he earns 5,500MT per month. He approached Hluvuku and solicited a loan for 15,000MT to purchase more products and satisfy the demand of his customers. This is Tomas' first loan through Hluvuku and Kiva for 15,000MT which will be used to purchase more products. He is confident that he will pay the loan off before the due date so he can request a new loan to construct his own establishment and cease being mobile.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sell grocery store products

loans.name: Pedro Joaquim

texts.pt:
NB. Não foi possível retratar a foto no local do negocio devido a distancia.

Pedro Joaquim C. nasceu em Gaza tem 44 anos de idade, vive maritalmente é pai de 6 filhos com idades compreendidas entre os 2 aos 22 anos. 5 é que vão a Escola. para além dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pela sua irmã enviando lhe 500mt ao mês e consegue poupar por 1.000.00MT porque conta com ajuda da sua esposa que também é docente. 

Pedro Sai de Gaza após concluir a 5ª classe é transferido para uma Escola privada a custo do Estado onde fez a 10ª classe, consegue fazer o curso de professorado é afecto para trabalhar no Centro de Formação de Professores na Vila de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia com a categoria de Director do Internato auferindo 7.000.00MT durante 20 anos, de seguida ganha uma bolsa de estudo (nível superior em freqüência). Assim devido à distância e custo de transporte (Namaacha – Maputo e vice versa) diário aproxima se a Hluvuku solicitando um empréstimo, o 1º no valor de 14.000.00MT e o 2º também de 14.000.00MT para dar inicio do seu negócio na tentativa de aumentar a renda familiar. Hoje para além de ser docente tem vendido acessórios de automóvel tal com (óleo, filtros, faróis) adquiridos na África do Sul gastando 5.000.00MT em cada viagem e tendo de lacro um valor de 2.000.00MT tendo semanalmente, a venda é feita por encomendas e pagas em prestações.


Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Pedro na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva no valor de 14.000,00mt para compra e venda de acessorios para automoveis. O primeiro de 14.000.00MT foi usado para dar inicio do seu próprio negócio, o segundo de 14.000.00MT foi usado para aumentar o volume do stock e pede este terceiro de 14.000.00MT que será usado para comprar acessórios do carro para revenda. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto, pois conta com ajuda da sua esposa que também é docente.
texts.en:
Born in Gaza, 44 year-old Pedro Joaquim C. lives with his partner and six children ages 2 to 22, five of whom are still in school. In addition to providing for his family, he also supports his sister by sending her a monthly allowance of 500mt. With the help of his wife's salary as a teacher, he is able to save 1.000.00mt per month. Pedro left Gaza after finishing 5th grade, when he was transferred to a private school. After finishing 10th Grade and getting his teaching credentials from the Center for Teachers' Education-Namaacha, he started working as director of a Boarding School located on the border of Swaziland. He worked taught there for 20 years. Upon getting a scholarship to a university in Maputo and in order to afford the high extra transportation costs of going back and forth from Namaacha to Maputo, he applied for a couple of loans with Hluvuku to start and stock a business of buying and selling car products and accessories such as oil, filters, headlights, etc. For each 5.000.00MT he now spends per week buying merchandise in South Africa, he profits 2.000.00MT by seeling it in Namaacha. This is Pedros' third loan with Hluvuku and the first with Kiva. He plans to use the 14.000,00 to buy more products and accessories to sell. With the help of his wife, he is confident that he will be able to pay off the loan before its term expires.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more car products and accessories to sell

loans.name: Amy Coly

texts.fr: Amy Coly S., 50 ans, avec 07 enfants en charge est membre du Banc Villageois de NIAFOR depuis 7 ans et demis. Avec son crédit elle envisage renforcer son activité de vente de balais, de jus de citron et de pain de singe. Elle écoule son produit à la capital(Dakar)Les bénéfices générés lui ont permis d'équiper sa maison et de prendre en charge la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Amy Coly S. is 50 years old and responsible for three children. She ha been a member of the Niafor Village Bank for the last seven and a half years. With her loan, she plans to strengthen her business of selling brooms, lemon juice and "pain de singe" (otherwise known as baobab, a popular fruit). She sells her products in Dakar, the capital. The profits earned have allowed her to furnish her house and meet the needs of her childrens education.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her business

loans.name: Antonio Pedro

texts.pt:
Antonio Pedro B. nasceu em Inhambane tem 40 anos de idade vive maritalmente. É pai de 2 filhos a primeira de 10 e o segundo de 3 anos. A mais velha é que vai a Escola, para além dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pelos seus dois sobrinhos que vivem com ele em sua casa. Consegue poupar 1.000.00MT por mês conta com ajuda da sua esposa que é funcionaria do Hotel Li bombos, e ganha uma pensão mensal de 1.500MT ao mês.

Antonio quando freqüentava a 4ª classe do antigo sistema é recrutado para cumprir o serviço militar obrigatório durante 3 anos, depois sai de Inhambane para vila de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia a procura de emprego onde começa a trabalhar como ajudante numa carpintaria.  Mas devido a sua ambição opta em abrir sua própria carpintaria em sua casa tem como melhor encomenda (cama, cristaleira, porta e aparador) tem uma receita mensal de 5,000. 00mt.
Aproxima se a Hluvuku e solicitou o primeiro empréstimo no valor de 5.300.00MT para dar inicio da sua obra. O 2º e o 3º de (8.000.00MT e 12.000.00MT) consecutivamente e conseguiu construir até a parte da viga. Com este quarto empréstimo no valor de 17.000.00MT pretende comprar materiais de construção (cimento, areia, e outros) concluir as mínimas partes da cobertura e brevemente mudar-se-á para sua própria casa.

Esta muito feliz porque em breve mudara para sua própria casa e esta confiante que vai pagar sem nenhum problema porque conta com ajuda da sua esposa e pretende levantar mais empréstimos para conclusão da obra e apetrecha mento.
texts.en:
Antonio Pedro B. was born in Inhambane. He is 40-years-old and is married. He is the father of two children. The oldest is 10, and the youngest is 3. The oldest one goes to school. In addition to his two children, he is responsible for his two nephews/nieces who live with him in his home. He manages to save 1,000 meticais per month and has the help of his wife, who works at the Hotel Li Bombos. She earns a monthly wage of 1,500 meticais.

When Antonio was in the fourth grade of the old school system, he was recruited to fulfill his obligatory military service for three years. Afterwards, he left Inhambane to look for a job in the village of Namaacha, which is on the border with Swaziland. Here he started to work as a carpeter's assistant. Due to his abition, he is choosing to open his own carpenter's shop in his house. He makes beds, hutches, doors, and cabinets. He receives a monthly wage of 5,000 meticais.

He came to Hluvuku and requested his first loan for 5,300 meticais to begin his work. He used his second and third loans (for 8,000 and 12,000 meticais) to construct part of his roof. With this fourth loan for 17,000 meticais, he will buy construction materials (cement, sand, etc.), to finish parts of the roof so he can move into his own home very soon.

He is very happy because he will soon move to his own home. He is confident that he will pay back the loan without any problem because he has the help of his wife, and he intends to receive more loans after this one so he can finish his work.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials (cement, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Celeste Alfredo

texts.pt:
Celeste Alfredo C. nasceu em Manhiça tem 56 anos de idade, é casada e mãe de 7 filhos com idades compreendidas entre os 18 aos 37 anos. 4 deles já estão empregados e 3 vão à escola. Para além dos três filhos responsabiliza se pela sua sobrinha que vive com ela em sua casa e consegue poupar 1.500.00MT por mês porque conta com ajuda dos seus filhos e do seu esposo.


Celeste sai de Manhiça para Vila de Namaacha com seu esposo este que foi transferido para trabalhar naquele Distrito. Dois anos depois da sua chegada ela inicia com o negócio de venda refeições nas barracas da fronteira que depois foram abolidas pelo Governo do Distrito devido à poluição do ambiente. Com ajuda do seu vizinho, que também era um grande criador, ela constrói uma capoeira na sua residência e inicia com o mesmo negócio e tornou se numa grande criadora de frangos. Tem criado no Maximo 100x5 caixas de pintos gastando 35.000.00MT e vende cada frango a 100.00mtx500frangos, cria em fases para poder vender alternadamente. Tem vendido a maior parte dos frangos a grosso, pois gastam menos ração. Rende cerca de 10.000,00MT em cada lote.

Aproxima se a Hluvuku e Kiva solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00MT para comprar pintos de 1 dia e fazer crescer (aumentar o volume de criação para calhar com a época festiva que se aproxima).

Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Celeste na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva. o primeiro de 10.000.00MT foi usado para comprar pintos, o segundo de 10.500.00MT  também usado para a mesma actividade. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para adquirir uma carrinha que lhe facilitara nos trabalhos diários
texts.en:
Celeste Alfredo C. was born in Manhiça, she is 56 years old, married and the mother of 7 children ages between 18 and 37. Four of them work and she suports the other three that only go to school, plus a niece that lives with them. She's able to save about 1.500,00MT (U$ 50) per month with the help of her husband and working children. Celeste left Manhiça years ago with her husband, who was transfered to Namaacha. Two years after her arrival, she starts a business selling meals at stands in the border of the country, which were later closed by the government due to the polution in the area. With the help of a neighboor, who raised chicken, she started doing it herself and saw her chick raising business grow. This is Celeste's third loan in the amount of 25.000,00MT (U$875) which she'll use to buy more chicks and improve her business. She hopes to pay it in no time so she can ask for another loan in order to buy a pickup van to help with her daily work.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of chicks for raising

loans.name: Allah Is One Group

texts.en:
Allah Is One is a group of 2 borrowers led by Fatu K.. Fatu is 35-years old and married with three children ages 6-15. She also cares for two orphans. Fatu is an illiterate due to muslims parents not educating their female children. Fatu and her family live in the  Sheriff Quarter, Voinjama, the capital of Lofa county in northern Liberia.

Fatu's business is selling house wares.She buys the goods wholesale and sells retail in the Voinjama central market, a business she has been doing for five years. Fatu's family depend on her business for their daily expenses, so she is eager to improve and expand what she sells. She is requesting a loan for this purpose. Fatu dreams of building a house for her and her family, and of giving her children better education.

loans.use: To purchase more house wares to improve business.

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. She is 27 years old and married with two children, She lives in Edo State, Nigeria.

Philomena is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase a fridge and generator. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge and generator

loans.name: Faridah's Group

texts.en: K. Faridah is a hard working and devoted 42-year-old lady. She is married and has four children ages 8-18 years old. For the past eight years, she has been raising poultry and running a small retail shop in Lugazi. Faridah is good businesswoman who knows how to take good care of her customers so they return and bring their friends. She is requesting a loan to expand what she offers for sale in her retail shop. She wishes to improve her income so she can educate her family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for retail shop

loans.name: Sofia

texts.pt:
Sofia nasceu em Maputo tem 39 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 3 filhos com idades entre os 11 aos 25 anos, Todos vão a Escola. Responsabiliza se pela sua afilhada que vive com ela em sua casa e pela sua mãe que vive em Ressano Garcia enviando lhe um valor de 500.00MT em cada três meses.

Sofia contrai matrimônio com seu marido em Rressano Garcia e seguidamente seu marido é transferido para vila de Namaacha na Fronteira de Suazilândia (guarda fronteira) então ela teve que pedir transferência no seu serviço (na saúde) para trabalhar no mesmo distrito com o seu marido. É funcionaria permanente a mais de 10 anos, Trabalha das 7h as 15:30h auferindo mensalmente um valor de 1.950.00MT e para aumentar a renda familiar inicia um negocio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidades na sua residência com ajuda do empréstimo que obteve na hluvuku no valor de 7,000.00mt, negocio esse que não teve sucesso por falta de tempo.Assim Sofia  aproxima se a Hluvuku solicitando um outro empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00MT para construção de um murro na sua residência dando mais conforto a sua família e ao jardim que esta ser danificado pela vizinhança e conta com ajuda do seu marido no reembolso do mesmo.


Este é o segundo empréstimo de Sofia na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva. O primeiro de 7.000.00MT foi usado para dar inicio do seu negócio, este segundo de 15.000.00MT será usado para compra de material de construção (cimento, areia blocos e outros) construção de um murro na sua residência e evitar que estraguem a sua relva. Está confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para mobilar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Sofia was born in Maputo, she's 39 years old, married and the mother of 3 children between 11 and 25 years old. They all go to school and Sofia supports them, plus a goddaughter who lives with them at their house, and her mother, sending her 500.00MT (U$ 18) every three months. She's been working in the healthcare industry for the past 10 years, and makes 1.950,00MT (U$70) per month. To increase her income, she started a business selling first necessity products out of her house, but that business wasn't successful because she couldn't find enough time to work on it. She is asking for a 15.000,00MT (U$525) in order to buy construction supplies (cement, sand and others) and improve her house by building new walls. She is confident she'll be able to pay it before the expiration so she can ask for another loan to buy furniture.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: construction supplies (sand, rock, cement, others)

loans.name: Andria

texts.en:
Andria A. is 38 years old and married with four children. She sells frozen foods, drinks and provisions to make a living.

Andria hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet P. is a 39-year old female entrepreneur from Kalubkob, Silang, Cavite.  Her husband is a community leader.  They have three children; the eldest is in college and the others are in high school.

Juliet owns a general store.  She went into business in 2006, the same year she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  Because she works hard, her business is continuously growing.  She uses her profits to support her children’s education.   

She is now on her 6th loan cycle with CCT and is requesting a new loan.  She will use the funds to purchase more items to sell at her general store.  Juliet dreams continuously improving her general store and having it evolve into a big store in the future.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase stock for general store

loans.name: Halawin

texts.en: Halawin M. is currently in the business of selling tea and bread at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more sugar for making tea. Halawin is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Halawin hopes to be able to purchase foodstuffs to cook and sell in her restaurant. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy sugar for her restaurant

loans.name: Joana

texts.pt:
Joana nasceu na Vila de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia tem 43 anos de idade, vive maritalmente é mãe de 6 filhos com idades compreendidas entre os 11 aos 30 anos. 5 é que vão a Escola e o mais velho já esta empregado. Para além dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pelos seus 5 netos que vivem com ela em sua casa.

Joana quando frequentava a 7ª classe fica grávida do seu primeiro filho e é expulsa de casa pelos seus progenitores, deste modo teve que ir ao lar e interrompe com os estudos devido à falta de tempo, pois seu marido é um grande camponês e passavam a maior parte do tempo cuidando das machambas. Devido ao seu marido que é polígamo com (5 mulheres tendo ficado com apenas duas e com 74 filhos) ela resolve apostar na agricultura para sua sobrevivência e a dos filhos, é agricultora a mais de 25 anos proprietária de 25hectares não tem empregados conta com ajuda dos seus filhos e enteados, tem plantado (milho, feijão manteiga, feijão nimbo, amendoim, melancia e abóboras) uma parte para revenda outra para o consumo familiar e para pagar os trabalhadores no tempo da sacha(comida pelo trabalho)tem como melhor produto o milho vendido na época da sementeira a lata e saco (120mtx30latas e a 360mtx50sacos)consecutivamente tendo um lucro no valor de 21.600MT.mas devido a doença do seu marido que encontra se internado ela fica sem fundo suficiente devido as despesas hospitalares e aproxima se a Hluvuku e Kiva solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00MT, para sustentar a sua actividade.


Este é o primeiro empréstimo de Joana na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva. Será usado para lavrar a terra e comprar insumos agrícolas para o lançamento da semente, esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto, pois conta com ajuda da sua rival e pedir outro empréstimo para o plantio de hortícolas em breve.
texts.en:
Joana was born in the Namaacha village in the border with Suazilandia, in Mozambique. She is 43 years old and lives with her husband and six children with ages between 11 and 30. Five of them go to school, and the older one is employed. Besides her children, she also suports her five grandchildren. They all live in her house. Joana got pregnant when she was in 7th grade, and her parents threw her out of the house. She couldn't continue her studies because she had to start working with her husband in the farms. Her husband has had other 4 wives and a total of 74 children, so Joana has to work hard to support herself and her children. She's been in this business for the past 25 years, and she has no employees, but counts with the help of children and sons-in-law. Her best selling product is corn. Her husband is now in the hospital and she has several medical bills to pay. She's asking for a 25.000,00MT (U$875) loan in order to invest in her business and make more money in the near future. She'll use the loan to work the land and buy seeds and fertilizers. She's positive she'll be able to pay the loan back on time.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of agricultural products and seeds

loans.name: Esohe

texts.en:
Esohe sells provisions, drinks, beef and foodstuffs. She is 39 years old and married with three children.

Esohe is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more beef and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beef and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Abdu's Group

texts.en:
Abdu is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is 38 years old and married with four children between the ages of 3 and 15 years old. He also cares for six dependents. Abdu has been a bread vendor in Lugazi for eight years and his business has been mostly affected by the changing seasons as well as bad debts. Amidst all this, Abdu makes 150,000/= a week and this helps him pay school fees for his children and dependents, as well as save for future developments. He ensures that he makes and sells quality bread and this increases his sales. 

Abdu has a dream of expanding his bakery so he can make more bread per day, plus cakes for increased income. He also vies to educate his children to the highest level of learning for self sustainability in the future. At the moment, Abdu needs a loan to help purchase more baking supplies to increase output.

loans.use: Purchase more baking supplies to increase output

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan J. sells green vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and pulses (edible seeds of legumes) to sell.  Susan is 40 years old and is married to a peasant. She has four children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase beans and edible seeds for resale

loans.name: Haurat's Group

texts.en:
Haurat is a 27-year-old mother of four children between the ages of 1 and 7 years old. She also cares for other dependents and siblings, and most of them are in primary and kindergarten schools. She has had a video library/hall and a canteen in Buziika for four years, where she sells electric stock and appliances. She is able to make 50,000/= as profits a week, and, although this is still small, she hopes for it to increase. She is usually happier when it is the league/football season because this brings in more revenue. 

Haurat has a dream of turning her video hall into a cinema hall, as well as educating all her children to the highest level. At the moment, Haurat needs a loan to help buy a mixer for improved video output and disco. She is such a hard working, friendly and determined lady with a strong drive to succeed.

loans.use: Buying a mixer for an improved video output and disco

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida H., 33, has a food market stall in Silang, Cavite, where she also lives with her husband, Eduardo, 35, a driver, and their two children who are in grade school.

She has been selling fruits, vegetables, fresh meat and fish for two years.  Because electronic load credit for mobile phones is in demand, she also tried it and proved it to be a worthwhile additional source of income. Zenaida now earns a net income of PHP 16,000 per month. From her profits, she was able to purchase a motorcycle.

She is now on her seventh loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She joined the cooperative in 2007. Zenaida has applied for a new loan in the amount of PHP 19,000 as additional capital for her food market business.

Zenaida desires to have her own public market someday. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her food market business

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en:
Kamala A. is a 33-year-old entrepreneur who cares for her two children. For the past three years, she has run her own grocery store. She started her business with the help of her husband and $200 U.S. dollars in capital.

At her grocery store, Kamala sells different kinds of foodstuffs as well as kids' toys. She is requesting a loan of $2025 U.S. dollars in order to increase the number of products she sells. Let’s do our best to help this hard-working woman.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell in her grocery store.

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni C. sells for at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more food. Poni is 45 years old and is widowed. She has three children who attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Increase food inventory

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen sells clothes and jewelry to earn a living. She is a 46-year-old married woman with 6 children. She lives in Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for 10 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more jewelry and clothes to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is 50 years old and married with four children. She sells drinks and foodstuffs.

Roseline hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret has a business brewing and selling local alcohol. She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell. 

Margret is 29 years old and is married to a policeman. She has three children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children at higher institutions of learning.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is into tailoring and the sale of sarongs. She has been in this business for a long time. She is 53 years old and married with five children.

Roseline hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Kamala A

texts.en: Kamala A A. is 39 years old, and she sells a variety of goods, such as beverages, flour, pasta, and other items. She started her business in 2005 when hunger knocked at her door. She decided to borrow money from her friends and opened her store. Now she rents her store and dreams of building her own store one day. To reach her dream, she needs additional funds to increase the number of goods she sells. So she is requesting a loan of 1600 AZN.

loans.use: Purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
This is Antonina G., 42, a seasoned fruit dealer from Dasmarinas, Cavite. She lives with her husband, Alfredo, 48, a driver, and their six children in a middle-class house at a government subsidized relocation site.

Antonina has been selling bananas in wholesale and retail. She renovated part of her house to be a store room as well as selling area. She employs five neighbors working as porters and assistants attending to customers and farmers/merchants frequenting her house.  She earns more than PHP 35,000 a month.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006, but has been enjoying its many social benefits for community members. Antonina is applying for a new loan from the cooperative in the amount of PHP 25,000 as additional capital for her banana business.
 
Antonina dreams of having her own car that she can use to buy fruit from farmers and deliver that fruit to other merchants.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her banana vending business

loans.name: Molovemai Group

texts.en:
Molovemai is a group of three borrowers led by John D. K.. John is 51 years old and married with ten children between the ages of 4 and 29 years old. His children's education levels are from first grade to university senior. He also cares for 17 orphans. John is a high school graduate and a vocational school graduate. He and his family lives on the Lawazu Road the capital of Lofa county, northern Liberia.

John's business is general store.He buys items wholesale and sells to residents of Lawazu Road, Voinjama, the capital of Lofa county, northern Liberia. He has been running this business for two years and hopes to expand to a bigger store. 

John has been facing some financial problems with his business, but because he talks to his customers in a good manner and cleans his shop in order to encourage them to continue buying from him, he believes his business will get better. He needs this loan in order to purchase goods such as milk, batteries, candles, body cream, sugar, etc., to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase goods for resale

loans.name: Aramata

texts.fr: Aramata G., 45 ans, mariée avec 2 enfants en charge est membre du Banc Villageois de NIAFOR depuis 5 ans et demi. Elle a reçu 11 prêts qu'elle a toujours remboursés sans problème. Avec son crédit elle développe un commerce de d'arachide. Les bénéfices générés par son activité lui permettent de participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la maison, à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et à assurer la scolarisation de ses enfants
texts.en:
Aramata G. is 45 years old, married and responsible for two children. She has been a member of the Niafor Village Bank for the last 5 and a half years. She has taken out eleven loans and has duly repaid each without difficulty. With these loans she has built a peanut business. The profits earned through this business has allowed her to help with the household expenses, improve the family's living conditions and provided for the education of her children.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen her  small business activities.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael is 58 years old and married with 7 children. She sells foodstuffs and provisions. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to pull her business and family above poverty. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Beatrice's Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 27 years old and divorced with two children, ages 8 and 4 years old, who are in primary school. She also cares for her parents. She is a hard working and determined lady who has been sold agricultural produce in Namengo for seven years. At the moment, she is able to make 70,000/= as profits a week. With this, she is grateful for her loans since they enable her to have quality produce for her inventory, hence more revenue. She is faced with a lot of competition in her business, plus the scarcity of produce during some of the bad seasons. 

Beatrice has a dream of becoming a wholesale supplier to the rest of the people in her industry as well as building rental houses for her children. She needs a loan to help recapitalize her business since this enables her pay her children’s school fees on time. This is Beatrice’s 59th loan with her lending group from Pearl Microfinance Ltd.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce for resale

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
This is Clarita A., a 42-year-old fresh meat vendor from Silang, Cavite. She has three children, all attending school. She is married to Lysander, an architect.

Clarita has a meat shop in a nearby market. She sells fresh beef and pork meat. Her business is fairly new – she just started it last year, almost simultaneous with her joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  Over time, her meat shop has grown steadily to where her hands are always full handling orders and tending to buyer, so she decided to hire two assistants. She is now making at least PHP 25,000 a month. Her profits help her to send her kids to school.

She is now on her seventh loan cycle with the cooperative. She is in need of a loan in the amount of PHP 29,000 as additional capital. Clarita wishes to have her house renovated soon.


 
About CCT

This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her fresh meat vending business

loans.name: Kasmiro

texts.en:
Kasmiro M. sells bread, toothpaste, sugar, small bags of salt, etc., at her shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of sugar and salt to sell.  Kasmiro is 32 years old and is married to a peasant. She has six children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy spare parts for motor bikes to sell. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of sugar and salt to sell

loans.name: Proscovia's Group

texts.en:
Proscovia is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hard working lady and married with five children, ages 22, 20, 18, 12 and 3 years old. She also cares for her parents. Her eldest two children are at the University, two are in secondary school, and the youngest is still at home and soon joining nursery section. 

Proscovia is a businesswoman who has been selling first class clothes from a boutique in Lugazi central market for ten years. At the moment, she is able to make 350,000/= as profits a week. She is grateful for her loans because they help boost her business by enabling her to buy quality clothes for her inventory. She is working so hard to ensure that she becomes a wholesale supplier of clothes to other retailers, as well as be able to build rental houses for her children. Proscovia needs a loan to help buy more new clothes for resale from her boutique.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 46 years old and married with seven children. She sells fruits like bananas to make a living and has been in this business for fourteen years.

Agnes hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more fruit to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
This is Josephine I., a young entrepreneur from Dasmarinas, Cavite.  She lives with her husband, Segismundo, and their three children in a middle-class community.

Josephine started selling rice six years ago.  She started small. Now, she sells an average of 20 50-kilo bags of rice a month, which translates to a net income of 35,000 PHP a month. She also finds time to engage in direct selling of cosmetics and apparel. A small room adjacent to her house now serves as her warehouse. Another part of her store serves as a small office, where she accepts applications from female entrepreneurs registering for her direct selling business. 

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative just last year, but has been enjoying its many social benefits for community members. The loans from the cooperative provide stability for her business. She can now purchase rice in advance from a government operated warehouse at a lower cost. She is currently in need of additional capital in the amount of 10,000 PHP to purchase more rice.
 
Josephine is saving her profits early on in preparation for her children’s college education.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk for retail

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Khady M., 36 ans, mariée, avec 5 enfants en charge est membre du Banc Villageois de NIAFOR depuis 7 ans et demi. Elle a été 15 fois bénéficiaire de prêt et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Elle développe un commerce de poisson frais et d'huile de palme. Son objectif est d'améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et d'assurer la scolarisation de ses enfants
texts.en:
Khady M. is 36 years old, she is married and is financially responsible for 5 children. She has been a member of the village Bank NIAFOR for seven and a half years. She has received 15 loans and has never had a problem to pay them back. She is developing a retail business of fresh fish and palm oil. Her goal is to improve her family' s living conditions and to guarantee her children' s school fees.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her small retail activity

loans.name: Noadik

texts.en:
Noadik V. is currently sells local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials like charcoal, yeast, etc. Noadik is 32 years old and is married to a peasant. She has six children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase brewing materials like charcoal and yeast

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen fries akara (bean cakes) to sell within her community in Benin City, Edo State. She is 62 years old and is a widow with seven children.

Helen hopes for the loan of N80,000 to purchase more bags of beans and cooking oil to fry more akara to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of beans and cooking oil

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca B. is a 52-year-old general store owner from Dasmarinas, Cavite.  She is happily living with her husband, Carlos, 53, a driver, and their two children in a government relocation site for poor families.

Rebecca’s general store is yet a baby – she opened it only last year almost simultaneous with her joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. It is situated right in front of her house. Her store has grown steadily, accommodating the basic needs of her neighbors. Thanks to the loans provided to her by CCT, she can continuously stock up on grocery items and beverages. She also offers electronic load credits for mobile phones. She now earns a net of 17,000 PHP a month.

She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP as additional capital for her general store. She would buy more grocery items and soft drinks to sell at her store. This would be her third loan cycle with the cooperative.  She hopes to make her general store grow into a bigger grocery store to help even more her neighbors.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To re-stock on grocery items and soft drinks

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni E. is currently cultivates and sells green vegetables like okra, cabbages, etc., and is requesting a loan to purchase pesticide to spray her garden. Poni is 20 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the length of her garden.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase pesticide for her garden

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Angelique U. is 31 years old and is married with three children ages 2, 6 and 9. She also is responsible for an additional dependent who lives with the family and is 12 years old. Angelique and her family live in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Angelique recently (in 2008) opened a restaurant and employs three persons in her business. Her restaurant is open every day from 6:00 in the morning to 10:00 in evening.

Angelique is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to have sufficient working capital to purchase more fish and cooking oil for her restaurant. With this loan she hopes to increase her business, which will help her to serve more customers.

loans.use: To buy more fish and cooking oil for her restaurant

loans.name: Ramy

texts.en: Ramy is a 32-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He has owned a café since 2002 in his town, where he services the neighboring villages. He is the one to support his family along with his old brother. Today, Ramy is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase additional equipment in order to expand his job.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita E., 49, is a successful businesswoman from Silang, Cavite. Her husband, Fernando, assists her with her business. Their only child is now in elementary school.

Anita has been in business for five years now. She started small and a bit slow, but she has seen the dramatic growth of her business over the years.  She now has another grocery store outlet being managed by her husband. She hired a niece to assist them in attending to customers. The combined operations of their grocery outlets give them a monthly net income of 44,000 PHP.  Part of her earnings goes to the salary of her niece. She was also able to buy a delivery van, which they now use in their business.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005, a year after opening her first store. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative, so she has applied for a new loan in the amount of 49,000 PHP to purchase more grocery items for both stores. This is her eighth loan with the cooperative.

Anita believes that education is the most precious gift she can give to her child, so she and her husband work hard hand-in-hand to be able to send their child to school up to college.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell at her store

loans.name: Matthew

texts.en:
Matthew is 37 years old and married. He owns a computer center where he offers computer services to his clients in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. He also sells stationery.

Matthew is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more stationery to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery to sell

loans.name: Moussaba Martine

texts.fr: Moussouba Martine D., 37 ans, mariée, 05 enfants en charge est membre du Banc Villageois de NIAFOR depuis 3 ans. Elle développe un petit commerce d'huile de palme et de balais artisanal. En moyenne, elle donne une participation mensuelle de 10 000 francs CFA pour les dépenses de la famille. Elle contribue à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et à la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Moussouba Martine D., aged 37, is married and has five children to support. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de NIAFOR for three years. She is developing a small business selling palm oil and artisanal brooms. On average, she contributes 10,000 francs CFA each month towards covering family expenses. She's helping to improve her family's living conditions and to provide an education for her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To advance her small-scale business

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan E. is currently in the business of selling shorgum and is requesting a loan to extend the floor of her store. Juan is 45 years old and is married to an engineer in the water sanitation commission. She has three children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To extend the floor of her store

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 34 years old and married with two children. He has been working as a farmer since 1994 to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Today, Mohamad is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy an agriculture delivery van to satisfy the demand of the market and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy a van

loans.name: Caritas

texts.en:
Cartas M. is 30 years old and is married with two children aged 1 and 4 as well as one dependent of unknown age that the family cares for. Cartas lives in Gasabo district, in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Cartas owns a small shop selling foodstuffs. She has owned this business since 2007 and employs one person. The hours of the business are from 6 a.m. to 12 a.m. most days… or thereabouts.

Cartas is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company which will help her to buy some necessary items like a fridge as well as additional inventory items such as groundnuts (peanuts), beans etc. Through buying these products she believes she will better serve her customers and earn more profits to improve her living situation.

loans.use: To buy a fridge and additional inventory items

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 20 years old. He has owned a ground compressor since 2007. He works at the demand of the clients. He works hard with his brother to satisfy the needs of the family. Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan of $600 to renovate the compressor and buy a new one to attract more clients.

loans.use: To renovate his compressor and buy a new one

loans.name: Elias

texts.en: Elias is a very hardworking married man and father of two young children. He has been working as a sanitary worker since 2000 to earn enough income to satisfy the needs of his family. Elias is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy more merchandise required by his clients.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Lozio's Group

texts.en: M. Lozio is a friendly, hard working and determined married man and the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a businessman in the tailoring trade. He has been in this business for 10 years. One of the major challenges in his business is the seasonality of his business, leading to the scarcity of customers yet the needs keep coming in. Lozio makes 250,000/= profit a week and this helps him pay school fees and cater to other family needs in time. Because Lozio is able to have quality materials for his business, he has been able to acquire tenders like making uniforms for schools and for other functions. He wishes to expand his business further and, if possible, start a tailoring school and teach more people the same trade. Lozio needs a loan to help buy more material to make new clothes.

loans.use: To buy material to make new clothes.

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope U. is 30 years old and is married with one child who is three years old. She also cares for a dependent who is 14 years old. The U. family lives in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

In her community, Hope owns a small shop selling a variety of different kinds of products as seen in her photo. In this business she has two years experience and employs one person as a helper.

Hope is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more inventory such as rice and cooking oil as well as equipment like a fridge which will allow her to sell more cold products, beverages, etc. This will help to expand her business to serve more customers.

With the profit she hopes to make from this loan, Hope plans to pay the school fees of her child and to save money for the future.

loans.use: To buy a fridge and additional inventory

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is 45 years old and married with three children. She sells provisions. She lives in Benin City, Edo State. She hopes for a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is 42 years old and married with six children. They are between 1 and 23 years old.  All her children go to school .She resides and owns a five- room house where she is staying with eight people. Betty takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water.  She is a retailer selling charcoal in Makerere Kikoni. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for 10 years and with also with MCDT for ten years, servicing her 20th loan.  She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises because she works from her home. Betty sells to all categories of people at both retail and wholesale. She buys her charcoal from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, so she incurs transport costs to and from the market. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season as she works in an open place. Betty wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She hopes to see her business grow stronger and start selling only at wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Ibiduni

texts.en: Ibiduni sells cooked foods like àmàlà and soup. Àmàlà is made from yam or plantain. Ibiduni is 47 years old and married with four children. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more plantain to make àmàlà to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plantain to cook more àmàlà to sell

loans.name: Qatun Hayta Group

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=102263&_tpos=1&_tpg=1 

El Banco Comunal Qantu Hayta, se encuentra ubicado en la comunidad D. Vischongo, distrito del mismo nombre, provincia D. VilcasH., departamento D. Ayacucho. Esta comunidad esta ubicada a 03 horas D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, la actividad principal D. la comunidad es la agricultura. 

Aydee es soltera, se dedica a la venta D. comida en su propio restaurante, negocio en el cual es apoyada por sus tíos. Aydee requiere D. un préstamo para la compra D. víveres e insumos para su restaurante. Aydee tiene como meta terminar sus estudios D. gastronomía y hacer crecer su negocio. 

Saturnina es casada y tiene 9 hijos. Saturnina se dedica a la venta D. animales, como carneros, cabras y cerdos, negocio que comparte con su esposo. Saturnina requiere D. un préstamo para la compra D. mas animales. A Saturnina le gustaría tener una chacra en el campo, para lograr su meta, ella ya se encuentra ahorrando.
texts.en:
First Loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=102263&_tpos=1&_tpg=1 The communal bank “Qantu Hayta”, is located in the community of Vischongo, in a district of the same name, in the VilcasH. province, in the department of Ayacucho. This community is located three hours from Ayacucho. People mostly farm in this area. Aydee is single and makes a living selling food in her restaurant. Her aunts and uncles help her with the business. Aydee needs a loan to buy food and supplies for her restaurant. Aydee plans to finish her gastronomy studies and grow her business Saturnina is married and has nine children. Saturnina sells animals like rams, goats, and pigs. She and her husband share this business. Saturnina needs a loan to buy more animals and she would also like to have a pond in the countrysiD.. She is already saving so she can meet her goal

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The communal bank "Qantu Hayta" ask for a loan of 6,800 soles for its 12 members to invest in their businesses.

loans.name: Ronald's Group

texts.en: K. Ronald is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is 23 years old and single with no children. He takes care of himself. Ronald has operated a cinema hall in Ngogwe trading centre for two and a half years and his major business challenges are the high power costs which are on and off, the high transport costs to get the CD’s, as well as the low population in the market. He is able to make 35,000/= a week profit and he hopes for this to increase.
